Unusual data volume patterns in traffic.Action: Analyze Zeek conn.log and http.log for traffic to common legitimate web services (e.g., social media, cloud storage). For each session, calculate the ratio of bytes sent vs. bytes received by the client. Identify sessions with unusually high client-to-server data volume ratios using descriptive statistics, percentiles, or outlier detection methods (e.g., IQR).

Network connections from suspicious proc.Action: Correlate Windows Event ID 4688 (Process Creation) with Zeek conn.log. Identify network connections originating from newly created or unusual processes (processes not in a known baseline or with low frequency of occurrence across endpoints) communicating with legitimate web services frequently used for C2. Investigate processes exhibiting network activity that deviates significantly from established baselines using correlation analysis.

Access to legitimate web services (e.g.,.Data: Zeek conn.log; Zeek http.log; Windows Event ID 4624; Windows Event ID 4688
Access to legitimate web services (e.g.,.Action: Establish a baseline of legitimate web service access patterns (frequency, time of day, data volume) for user accounts and endpoints using Zeek logs and Windows logon data (4624). Use time series analysis and descriptive statistics to identify deviations, such as access from accounts or endpoints with no prior history, or access at unusual times or frequencies. Correlate with process creation (4688) to identify the application initiating the connection.

Suspicious request methods, patterns, or.Action: Analyze Zeek http.log for connections to common legitimate web services. Identify and flag unusual HTTP methods (e.g., excessive PUT/POST requests to cloud storage, unexpected GET requests to user profile pages), unusual URL paths or parameters, or rapid sequences of requests. Use frequency analysis to identify rare patterns and correlation analysis to link suspicious HTTP behavior to other anomalies.
